byline.contributor: David D. Kirkpatrick and Merna Thomas contributed reporting.

abstract: Egyptian Judge Hassan Farid sentences journalists Mohamed Fahmy, Baher Mohamed and Peter Greste, from Al Jazeera English news channel, to three years in prison on what legal experts say are politically-motivated charges; unexpectedly harsh verdict defies stated preference of Pres Abdel Fattah el-Sisi for deportation of the men rather than criminal trial; some see ruling as sign that Sisi no longer commands complete obedience from government officials.
lead_paragraph: The case has become a source of international embarrassment for the government, highlighting its sweeping crackdown on opponents as well as freedom of expression after the military takeover in 2013.

headline.main: Al Jazeera Journalists Sentenced to 3 Years in Prison in Egypt
headline.print_headline: Egypt Gives Journalists 3 Years in Prison

snippet: The case has become a source of international embarrassment for the government, highlighting its sweeping crackdown on opponents as well as freedom of expression after the military takeover in 2013.
